update.description:
I've been analyzing the lifecycle and ownership patterns of the `Event` classes ([design doc PR here](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/pull-requests/33)), and I noticed a few issues. This PR makes some internal changes that shouldn't affect any external code. The changes are organized by commits.

* a063142: Remove unused constructors for `event::Connection` and `event::ConnectionPrivate`

* 3b178e6: Make `ConnectionPrivate` not visible, use `unique_ptr` in `event::Connection`

* 98f43c9: Store copy of `boost::function` directly in `EventConnection` instead of wrapping in a smart pointer

* 91d232f: fix `Event` PIMPL pattern: the `EventPrivate` class was declared as visible, so it wasn't really following the PIMPL pattern. Since it was only holding one variable (`bool signaled`), it was moved to be a `protected` member of `Event`. A `unique_ptr` is then used to hold the `EventTPrivate` class. There was also a weird typo in the `Signal` function with 7 parameters.

* a0a0825: fix typo: Deleteing

The migration and changelog should probably be updated.
update.title: Event classes: some internal refactoring

content.raw:
I made a few small changes:

* dd15341c660f Deprecate `Connection::GetId()` and replace with `Connection::Id()`
* 13d18eaeb869 Add `Event::SetSignaled()` so `Event::signaled` can be private, add `Event::Signaled()` and deprecate `Event::GetSignaled()`
* de9460918301 add const to a function signature, whitespace and remove extra headers
content.html:
I made a few small changes:

  • dd15341c660f Deprecate Connection::GetId() and replace with Connection::Id()
  • 13d18eaeb869 Add Event::SetSignaled() so Event::signaled can be private, add Event::Signaled() and deprecate Event::GetSignaled()
  • de9460918301 add const to a function signature, whitespace and remove extra headers

content.raw:
Nice work. I've taken what you've done a step further in [event_lifecycle_nate](#!/osrf/gazebo/branch/event_lifecycle_nate?dest=event_lifecycle#diff). This could become a separate pull request. The changes are:

1. Completely removed PIMPL. Here are the reasons:
    a. The Event system is suppose to be as fast and efficient as possible since a lot of critical components rely on it. For a bit of history, these classes replaced boost's signal and slots because the overhead was extreme.
    b. The private member variables have not changed in many years (probably close to 4 or 5 years), so I consider it fairly stable.

1. Deprecated `Get` functions.

1. Moved the `EventConnection` class into the `EventT` class.

1. Replaced boost:functions with std::functions. The signature is the same, so people should not be affected.
content.html:
Nice work. I've taken what you've done a step further in event_lifecycle_nate. This could become a separate pull request. The changes are:

  1. Completely removed PIMPL. Here are the reasons: a. The Event system is suppose to be as fast and efficient as possible since a lot of critical components rely on it. For a bit of history, these classes replaced boost's signal and slots because the overhead was extreme. b. The private member variables have not changed in many years (probably close to 4 or 5 years), so I consider it fairly stable.

  2. Deprecated Get functions.

  3. Moved the EventConnection class into the EventT class.

  4. Replaced boost:functions with std::functions. The signature is the same, so people should not be affected.

* 91d232f: fix `Event` PIMPL pattern: the `EventPrivate` class was declared as visible, so it wasn't really following the PIMPL pattern. Since it was only holding one variable (`bool signaled`), it was moved to be a `protected` member of `Event`. A `unique_ptr` is then used to hold the `EventTPrivate` class. content.raw: I think they are mostly compatible, but events can be pretty tricky, so I didn't want to change lots of things in a single PR.
content.html: I think they are mostly compatible, but events can be pretty tricky, so I didn't want to change lots of things in a single PR.

content.raw: Sure. I just thought that there was already some internal conversion going on from std to boost because we're using `std::bind` to connect several events. But I don't really know what it does.
content.html: Sure. I just thought that there was already some internal conversion going on from std to boost because we're using std::bind to connect several events. But I don't really know what it does.

content.raw: I did that while testing, but it made the diff kinda nasty, so I didn't want to make the rest of this hard to read. Can I save this for another PR too?
content.html: I did that while testing, but it made the diff kinda nasty, so I didn't want to make the rest of this hard to read. Can I save this for another PR too?

content.raw: I'll save that for another pull request if that's ok. I know the `std::function` and `boost::function` implementations are similar, but I didn't want to risk affecting all the downstream code for this PR.
content.html: I'll save that for another pull request if that's ok. I know the std::function and boost::function implementations are similar, but I didn't want to risk affecting all the downstream code for this PR.
